surfgeopy.quadrature_points.quadrule_on_simplex(deg)[source]ïƒ
Parameters:

  • deg (Algebraic degree of precision of the rule.) â€“ Algebraic degree of precision of the rule.

  • 0] (CUBATURE RULE ON THE SIMPLEX [0 0; 0 1; 1) â€“

  • Legend â€“

  • #DEG (algebraic degree of precision.) â€“

  • #CARD (cardinality of the pointset.) â€“

  • #W- (negative weights.) â€“

  • #PT.O (points outside the simplex [0 0; 1 0; 0 1].) â€“

  • #M.E. (maximum moment error in inf norm.) â€“

  • points (Statistics of quadrature) â€“

  • M.E. (# | DEG | CARD | W- | PT.O|) â€“

surfgeopy.quadrature_points_gl moduleïƒ

surfgeopy.quadrature_points_gl.gauss_legendre_square(deg)[source]ïƒ

Gauss-Legendre cubature rule on the square [-1, 1]^2.

Parameters:

deg (int) â€“ Algebraic degree of precision of the rule.

Returns:

  • weights_ps (ndarray) â€“ n-by-1 array of single or double, weights of quadrature points.

  • quad_ps (ndarray) â€“ n-by-2 array of single or double, natural coordinates of quadrature points.

surfgeopy.quadrature_points_gl.q_gauss_legendre(n, Domain=array([- 1, 1]))[source]ïƒ

Generate quadrature weights and nodes for Gauss-Legendre quadrature rule.

An n-point Gauss-Legendre quadrature rule is of degree 2n-1; that is, it integrates all polynomials up to degree 2n-1 exactly.

Parameters:

  • n (int) â€“ Number of sample points and weights. It must be >= 1.

  • Domain (ndarray, optional) â€“ Refers to the domain of integration [a, b]. The default domain is the bi-unit interval [-1, 1].

Returns:

  • x (ndarray) â€“ 1-D ndarray containing the sample points.

  • w (ndarray) â€“ 1-D ndarray containing the weights.

Notes

The function constructs the symmetric tridiagonal matrix and computes the eigenvalues and eigenvectors to obtain the quadrature points and weights.

The next steps ensure that zero is zero, and the points and weights are symmetric.

If the integration domain [a, b] is different from the default [-1, 1], the points and weights are transformed accordingly.

surfgeopy.remesh.hashable_rows(data, digits=None)[source]ïƒ

We turn our array into integers based on the precision given by digits and then put them in a hashable format.

Parameters:

  • data ((n, m) array) â€“ Input data

  • digits (int or None) â€“ How many digits to add to hash if data is floating point If None, tol.merge will be used

Returns:

hashable â€“ Custom data type which can be sorted or used as hash keys

Return type:

(n,) array

surfgeopy.remesh.subdivide(vertices, faces, face_index=None, vertex_attributes=None, return_index=False)[source]ïƒ

Subdivide a mesh into smaller triangles.

Note that if face_index is passed, only those faces will be subdivided and their neighbors wonâ€™t be modified making the mesh no longer â€œwatertight.â€

Parameters:

  • vertices ((n, 3) float) â€“ Vertices in space

  • faces ((m, 3) int) â€“ Indexes of vertices which make up triangular faces

  • face_index (faces to subdivide.) â€“ if None: all faces of mesh will be subdivided if (n,) int array of indices: only specified faces

  • vertex_attributes (dict) â€“ Contains (n, d) attribute data

  • return_index (bool) â€“ If True, return index of original face for new faces

Returns:

  • new_vertices ((q, 3) float) â€“ Vertices in space

  • new_faces ((p, 3) int) â€“ Remeshed faces

  • index_dict (dict) â€“ Only returned if return_index, {index of original face : index of new faces}.

surfgeopy.remesh.unique_ordered(data, return_index=False, return_inverse=False)[source]ïƒ

Returns the same as np.unique, but ordered as per the first occurrence of the unique value in data. .. rubric:: Examples

In [1]: a = [0, 3, 3, 4, 1, 3, 0, 3, 2, 1] In [2]: np.unique(a) Out[2]: array([0, 1, 2, 3, 4]) In [3]: trimesh.grouping.unique_ordered(a) Out[3]: array([0, 3, 4, 1, 2])

surfgeopy.remesh.unique_rows(data, digits=None, keep_order=False)[source]ïƒ

Returns indices of unique rows. It will return the first occurrence of a row that is duplicated: [[1,2], [3,4], [1,2]] will return [0,1]

Parameters:

  • data ((n, m) array) â€“ Floating point data

  • digits (int or None) â€“ How many digits to consider

Returns:

  • unique ((j,) int) â€“ Index in data which is a unique row

  • inverse ((n,) int) â€“ Array to reconstruct original Example: data[unique][inverse] == data

surfgeopy.surf_integration moduleïƒ

surfgeopy.surf_integration.compute_surf_quadrature(ls_function, ls_grad_func, vertices, faces, interp_deg, lp_dgr, Refinement, fun_handle, deg_integration=14, quadrature_rule='Pull_back_Gauss')[source]ïƒ

Compute quadrature points and weights on curved triangles.

Parameters:

  • ls_function â€“ callable Zero-levelset function.

  • ls_grad_func â€“ callable Gradient of zero-levelset function.

  • vertices â€“ ndarray Array of vertex coordinates.

  • faces â€“ ndarray Array of face connectivity.

  • interp_deg â€“ int Interpolation degree.

  • lp_dgr â€“ int \(l_p\)-norm, which is used to define the polynomial degree.

  • deg_integration â€“ int, optional Degree of integration (default: 14).

  • quadrature_rule â€“ str, optional Quadrature rule type (â€˜Gauss_Legendreâ€™ or â€˜Gauss_Simplexâ€™).

Returns:

ndarray, ndarray, ndarray Quadrature points, weights, and offset array.

surfgeopy.surf_integration.integration(ls_function, ls_grad_func, mesh, interp_deg, lp_dgr, Refinement, fun_handle=<function <lambda>>, deg_integration=-1, quadrature_rule=None)[source]ïƒ

Compute integration of a function over curved triangles.

Parameters:

  • ls_function â€“ callable Zero-levelset function.

  • ls_grad_func â€“ callable Gradient of zero-levelset function.

  • mesh (str) â€“ The file path to the MAT file containing mesh data.

  • interp_deg â€“ int Interpolation degree.

  • lp_dgr â€“ int \(l_p\)-norm, which is used to define the polynomial degree.

  • Refinement â€“ int Refinement level.

  • fun_handle â€“ callable, optional Function to be evaluated on each quadrature point (default: lambda _: 1.0).

  • deg_integration â€“ int, optional Degree of integration (default: -1, use default configuration).

  • quadrature_rule â€“ str, optional Quadrature rule type (â€˜Gauss_Legendreâ€™ or â€˜Gauss_Simplexâ€™).

Returns:

Integration values for each curved triangle.

surfgeopy.q_gauss_legendre(n, Domain=array([- 1, 1]))[source]ïƒ

Generate quadrature weights and nodes for Gauss-Legendre quadrature rule.

An n-point Gauss-Legendre quadrature rule is of degree 2n-1; that is, it integrates all polynomials up to degree 2n-1 exactly.

Parameters:

  • n (int) â€“ Number of sample points and weights. It must be >= 1.

  • Domain (ndarray, optional) â€“ Refers to the domain of integration [a, b]. The default domain is the bi-unit interval [-1, 1].

Returns:

  • x (ndarray) â€“ 1-D ndarray containing the sample points.

  • w (ndarray) â€“ 1-D ndarray containing the weights.

Notes

The function constructs the symmetric tridiagonal matrix and computes the eigenvalues and eigenvectors to obtain the quadrature points and weights.

The next steps ensure that zero is zero, and the points and weights are symmetric.

If the integration domain [a, b] is different from the default [-1, 1], the points and weights are transformed accordingly.

surfgeopy.quadrature_split_surf_tri(ls_function, ls_grad_func, vertices, faces, interp_deg, lp_dgr, fun_handle, deg_integration, quadrature_rule, pnts, ws, index)[source]ïƒ

  • faces â€“ ndarray Array of face connectivity.

  • interp_deg â€“ int Interpolation degree.

  • lp_dgr â€“ int \(l_p\)-norm, which is used to define the polynomial degree.

  • deg_integration â€“ int Degree of integration.

  • quadrature_rule â€“ str, optional Quadrature rule type (â€˜Gauss_Legendreâ€™ or â€˜Gauss_Simplexâ€™).

  • pnts â€“ ndarray Quadrature points array.

  • ws â€“ ndarray Quadrature weights array.

  • index â€“ int Current index in the arrays.

Returns:

int

Updated index value.

surfgeopy.quadrule_on_flat(deg)[source]ïƒ

Quadrature rule

Parameters:

deg (int) â€“ Algebraic degree of precision of the rule.

Returns:

  • weights_ps (ndarray) â€“ n-by-1 array of single or double, weights of quadrature points.

  • quad_ps (ndarray) â€“ n-by-3 array of single or double, natural coordinates of quadrature points.

surfgeopy.subdivide(vertices, faces, face_index=None, vertex_attributes=None, return_index=False)[source]ïƒ

Subdivide a mesh into smaller triangles.

Note that if face_index is passed, only those faces will be subdivided and their neighbors wonâ€™t be modified making the mesh no longer â€œwatertight.â€

Parameters:

  • vertices ((n, 3) float) â€“ Vertices in space

  • faces ((m, 3) int) â€“ Indexes of vertices which make up triangular faces

  • face_index (faces to subdivide.) â€“ if None: all faces of mesh will be subdivided if (n,) int array of indices: only specified faces

  • vertex_attributes (dict) â€“ Contains (n, d) attribute data

  • return_index (bool) â€“ If True, return index of original face for new faces

Returns:

  • new_vertices ((q, 3) float) â€“ Vertices in space

  • new_faces ((p, 3) int) â€“ Remeshed faces

  • index_dict (dict) â€“ Only returned if return_index, {index of original face : index of new faces}.

surfgeopy.unique_ordered(data, return_index=False, return_inverse=False)[source]ïƒ

Returns the same as np.unique, but ordered as per the first occurrence of the unique value in data. .. rubric:: Examples

In [1]: a = [0, 3, 3, 4, 1, 3, 0, 3, 2, 1] In [2]: np.unique(a) Out[2]: array([0, 1, 2, 3, 4]) In [3]: trimesh.grouping.unique_ordered(a) Out[3]: array([0, 3, 4, 1, 2])

surfgeopy.unique_rows(data, digits=None, keep_order=False)[source]ïƒ

Returns indices of unique rows. It will return the first occurrence of a row that is duplicated: [[1,2], [3,4], [1,2]] will return [0,1]

Parameters:

  • data ((n, m) array) â€“ Floating point data

  • digits (int or None) â€“ How many digits to consider

Returns:

  • unique ((j,) int) â€“ Index in data which is a unique row

  • inverse ((n,) int) â€“ Array to reconstruct original Example: data[unique][inverse] == data
